Okay it seems some people are too stupid to understand the video properly, and have somehow used their false conclusions against veganism.

1) no, plants can't feel anything, they can't feel happiness, sadness, or suffering. They are simply more reactive than one would assume, but these reactions are automatic and do not involve any level of awareness or cognition (cause ofcourse, they have no central nervous system)

2) They do not feel pain either. Pain is a property of a sentient, mobile creature that leads an interactive life. Much unlike plants. If you're an animal walking around, you need to be able to learn what to pursue and what to avoid. Pain, suffering, and even other forms of positive stimuli that involve emotion and cognition are necessary for that. Plants lack all of these, they simply have the capacity to automatically detect some forms of negative stimuli (and perhaps some patterns, albeit without any level of understanding). A plant has ZERO benefits from being able to feel pain, since it can be continuously chomped on and never die, and is constantly trampled under the feet of mobile creatures. Sure, you can play a semantics game by changing the definition of pain to simply "harm detection", in which case plants do 'feel pain', but that's misleading as they really don't 'feel' at all.

3) It is even overwhelmingly likely that invertebrates also don't feel pain, so let alone plants.

4) assuming (falsely) that plants suffer, eating an animal results in far more damage since that animal needs to eat a lot more plants than you would if you directly ate plants (besides the fact than non-vegans dont eat meat exclusively). In fact, through every stage of the food cycle, 90% of consumed energy is lost as heat, so the closer you are to the bottom of the food cycle, the less resources, and thus suffering, you will be causing.
And there was no explanation HOW the plants could "hear" and have "memory".

Thinking requires neurons.
Plants don't have neurons. 
Therefore, plants cannot think, but they do react to hormones and other environmental stimuli-- as do ALL genes. That's not thinking, it's chemistry.

However, natural selection makes it APPEAR that there's some "intelligent design" behind it; for example, plants waste energy growing fruit, simply so that animals will come eat it, and trample competing vegetation around it, while at the same time providing manure for the tree; and so that tree survives while others are trampled. . . Likewise, the pheremone which ripens other fruit, only applies to the same species of tree, which increases its numbers over competing types, etc. 
It's the old "selfish gene" concept in action.

Sooner or later everyone will have to adopt a primarily vegetarian diet. Natural ecosystems can only support 10 million humans. Yet here we are with a populace of 7 billion. it takes 800L of water to produce a kg of wheat, as opposed to the 5000L required to prepare a kg of beef. Vegetarian diets are much more sustainable. If everyone were to become vegetarians, it would spell out the end of world hunger. The amount of vegetarians there are now are too insignificant to make a difference. Perhaps all you are doing is making meat cheaper for others, as there is slightly less demand? Vegetarianism will only make a difference when whole governments make efforts to shift the whole food industry into a more sustainable one.

I love how everyone acts like they know the science behind what they are saying in these comments. I must make some things clear for people who have made diet choices and are going to comment on said choice because it is excruciating to read some of these comments. Sooo, here's the deal: We as humans have ADAPTED to be somewhat omnivorous, but since there are living vegetarians and vegans who are also happy, I would conclude that a lifestyle like theirs is successful. People just having a diet of meat, not so much. Do you know the reason why we aren't carnivores? It is because of our ability to process it. How many times have eaten raw meat? I pretty sure your answer is zero times because we need fire/heat to process it before it reaches our stomach. That is the only reason we can eat meat. But before every vegan/vegetarian jumps for joy, remember that meat is what allowed our species to evolve a bigger brain and a smaller digestion system. Nowadays, we can just aim for the optimal amount of vitamins and minerals. I mean honestly we could just synthesize them and take a mixture or multiple pills everyday. But that would probably take an excessive amount of energy and be less efficient whereas life does the work for you and is environmentally sound. It is best to have a nice variety in one's diet and everyone seems to be doing that just fine. We all, at least potentially, get all of our vital minerals (vita-mins :P) and nutrients with our current diets, so it all comes down to efficiency and environmental-friendliness. Here is the ironic part though to all of this, even though adding meat to our diet sparked our intelligence in the past leading to civilization, continuing to eat meat will eventually be our downfall.
Here's why: Let's say we have 2 acres of grass. Now let's take a cow that eats that grass. While the 2 acres of grass take... well... 2 acres to grow, a cow takes about the same amount. Now I am pretty damn sure that the total energy in 2 acres of grass far outweigh the total energy of the cow. To add to that, if you've taken a biology and/or ecology course you should know this, the primary consumer (the cow) obtains 100% of the total energy from the plant whilst the secondary consumer (the human) only obtains 10% of the original total energy. By eating meat, you lose 90% of the total potential energy that you could have gained by eating the plants directly and the plants require a LOT less space. This in turn leads to deforestation. When my biology teacher told my class this it changes my perspective on things. Although both types of farms cause deforestation (horrible rice farms in Madagascar and horrible beef farms in Brazil) the plants win again as they do not require as much space. This means that the nowadays high demand for meat actually speeds up the global climate change that we are all starting to feel.
This argument is not about how cute the animals are or how cruel the farms are (even though I'm pretty sure they're not really cruel) and anyone who devolves the statements back to that are pathetic. This is more about efficiency and the continuation of the world as we know it. If we want complete efficiency in our diet balancing meat and plants, we should balance between plants and insects (which are way more efficient to farm than any mammal). So for the vegan/vegetarian who empathizes with lesser living things and to the omnivore who sees no harm in eating lots of steak and pork etc., please look at the facts and base your decision on that. This believe it or not could decide whether we live in a beautiful and efficient world or an ugly and inefficient world. The proof is in the pudding and now you have to willingly take a spoonful.

Reminds me of a study I'd read about. A series of trees of the same type were planted on opposing sides of a lake. A worm that harms plants was introduced to one series of trees while the others didn't have this worm. Otherwise, all the environmental variables were the same. It was found, through a long series of roots systems the trees were essentially communicating and the healthy trees without these worms actually sent nutrients and such to the dying trees in an attempt to save them; however, this didn't work.
It was later, the infected trees were burned down to keep the infection from spreading to other areas, in doing so an amazing discovery was made. Through the root system an electrical disruption on a small scale was coming from the burning trees that if put in audio, would be the same as a mammal screaming in pain.

I still don't believe that plants can "think", or sense their environment. They can react to their environment, but that is due to the environment directly influencing the plant. In humans, and other fauna, the input(Senses) goes into the brain. Based on that input, the brain makes a decision, and the organism reacts, so there are three stages. However, when a plant "interacts" with it's environment, it is actually a direct reaction. Instead of input moving into the brain, which decides the output based on that input, the input directly results in the output. There is nothing being sensed, it is just a chemical reaction.

Okay, just throwing my two cents in here. Since plants don't move, they interact with the flora surrounding them. Could this mean that there is some form of "brain" or cognitive processing center in the roots? Sure, it's not a "true" brain, but they have to have somewhere to store the memory and senses, and why not somewhere that generally doesn't move? Yes, I know that roots are primarily used for the absorption and dispersal of water and nutrients through the plant, but doesn't the brain do that too? It could explain why when you uproot a plant, it dies. Again, yes, I know. Water and nutrients. But when you remove the brain from a person, no matter their physical health, or amount of water or nutrients in them and moving around, they usually die too. But this is about small plants. What about trees? Same theory applies, but what about leafs? They grow off the tree, and therefore use the same way to live as the tree does. Could this mean there is a form of "brain" in the leaves too? At least something proportional to the tree's. Like a baby to it's parent. Again, this is just a thought and opinion. Can plants "think" though? I'd certainly argue no, not by any of the more useful definitions of "thinking". ;) There's another related question: can plants feel pain? I present a neat argument by a 14 year old arguing that plants don't feel pain:

“There’d be no reason for them to evolve that,” he said. “Pain is a warning so you can get away from something like a predator, or take your hand out of the fire. But plants can’t move anyway, so pain wouldn’t be an advantage. It wouldn’t help one plant survive to reproduce more than another one. It would just…hurt.”

Very interesting video but none of this is evidence towards plants actively thinking... All of this can be explained by cells reacting to external stimuli via intracellular pathways that evolved over time.... The last example of a plant "flinching" when touched but when dropped multiple times does not respond can easily be explained. Plants have a slow metabolism and therefore can not produce the energy currency (ATP or equivalent) to sustain multiple contractions when subjected to a series of stimuli... It's equivalent to the patellar tendon reflex, we do not consciously control it, so neither do plants

Nothing described here, as for the activity of the involved plants, has more to do with "thinking" than me having to sneeze upon the intrusion of my airways with foreign particles.

It doesn't hold up to the own definition the guy gave at the end of the video, e.g. the ability to solve problems:
The problems are not being solved by the plants brooding about it - they already have been solved by thousands of years of evolution, whereas the involved plants merely carry it out.
So if you need to ascribe the ability of something doing the "thinking" here, it's "mother earth" (and cosmic radiation and and...), not any group of plants by themselves.

And since it took this uber entity millions of years to "think" about those things, it is, compared to humans, actually pretty dumb, not super smart as claimed in the video. Human engineers will design comparable systems in much less time.

All those facts about plants are impressive and amazing, but the thinking analogy is silly. Plants don't have brains or a nervous system, so by definition they can't "think" or "be smart". All of the processes you described are nastic responses and evolutionary traits.

They don't make a conscious decision to smell like dead corpse to detect bugs, release toxins to kill animals, or exchange nutrients. They just do it because those traits allowed them to survive natural selection. 2:46 You don't "measure intelligence" by "solving problems", "interacting", or "working in groups" if none of those processes are made consciously.

I know this video is just a symbolic way to illustrate fun facts about plants, but many of your subscribers are kids who take everything literally, and if they sincerely ask you afterwards if their brocolli can feel pain, you didn't explain it well. That's the problem with pop science, and why you shouldn't oversimplify a complex concept.

Here's a good read if you're interested in more: http://www.skepdic.com/plants.html

Reflex is just not the same as reasoning, and I'm not really sure how you can call reflex "thinking". An individual plant solves no problems, it merely reacts the way evolution has led it to, after many many generations of disadvantageous reactions (or lack of a reaction) leading to the downfall of the less well-equipped members of its species. It has a set of pre-determined (not reasoned on the fly) mechanisms to react to specific situations, and as much as it pains people to imagine (I personally find it endlessly fascinating), carrion plants, for instance, never sat down and thought, "you know what would attract all the beetles? If I dress up like rotting meat!" It's just that the one (actually many, but the scope of evolution is hard to comprehend) that looked/smelled the most like rotting meat attracted the most beetles and therefore had the most "children." Those "children" then came to dominate the overall population of that particular plant type.

Reasoning is surely not a pre-requisite for feeling, though, as it's well documented that mammals, at the very least, feel a range of emotions (anxiety, loss, expectation, relief, among the more complex ones). It is in fact quite interesting to ask whether or not plants feel, and to what degree, and what exactly that means. Which I suppose leads to me to wonder, Why does AsapSCIENCE figure we'd be more interested in "thinking" than in "feeling"?

You just made a video describing all of these seemingly cool biological reactions; these plants have developed a system for recognizing certain stimuli and responding appropriately through evolution. Geeze...all the arguments about food... how about instead of arguing over if people should eat meat at all or should eat plants at all we actually try treating the rest of the species on the planet with some respect?! 

The big problems we cause aren't caused because we kill other species to survive, but because we do so in dramatic excess.  The moral issues involved in the proction of our food isn't the fact that we modify it, but that we do so in ways that are often harmful and unsustainable.  They are misunderstood and impact the environment around them (often very differently from how people THINK they impact the surroundings).

We have to eat to survive.  Some of us even essentially have to eat meat to survive (inability to find or adjust to alternatives that have a few specific nutrients in them; increased need for protien/change in balance necessary due to certain medical conditions).  We do not, however, have to stop caring about our impact.  We don't have to disregard mistreatment and overuse of various parts of the ecosystem.  We CAN attempt to respect the species with which we coexist, whether we eat meat or not.

And all the vegetarians freaking out because people are making fun of your lifestyle.  Well...we're not all actually making fun of it - we're making fun of a certain set of arguments often used within it, and we're doing that because we're tired fo being insulted, ridiculed, and made out to be bad people because we maintain our survival by eating once-living animal material as well as once-living plant material.  It's been going on for years in ways that often are anything but meant as lighthearted or jokes.

I think some of the conclusions are questionable. I should start by saying CORRELATION DOES NOT EQUAL CAUSATION! There certainly is a correlation between corn releasing chemicals when being eaten by caterpillars and parasitic wasps being attracted to said chemicals to eat said caterpillars. But that doesn't necessarily mean the corn is willfully releasing chemicals with the intent to attract wasp. Another possible conclusion is that wasps have evolved to be attracted to those chemicals.

Mimosa pudica, much like the Venus flytrap, sundews and bladderworts, don't necessarily adapt to stimuli that are discovered to be non-threatening and therefore no longer react by rapidly moving. Although the mechanism behind their movement is poorly understood, many species have a limited ability to continuously move under repeated stimuli before they quite moving altogether.

These are all problems that plants have, because actually, the biggest difference between plants and animals, are that plants are sessile organisms. They're literally rooted in place. So on a very basic biological level, plants are often more complex than animals are.

The confusion here is that there are 3 levels of problem solving

Emergence is simply patterns that don't fall apart and remain stable for millions or billions of years.

Evolution can only happen when there is a mechanism for duplicating previous solutions and selecting the ones that work better over thousands of generations and millions of years.

Intelligence can actually perceive that a problem exists and reason in order to find a solution in anything from decades to milliseconds.

Intelligence can build a solution in the blink of an eye compared to the other methods of "problem solving", so much so, that I'm not even sure it is fair to say the one levels are even solving problems.
